name.text: 8.1.1.5 Exercise: Cramer's rule for solving simultaneous equations

questiontext.text:
Exercise 1 (paper exercise)

Use Cramerâ€™s rule to determine any and all solutions to the equations

\[\text{(a)}\ \ \ \ \begin{array}{rrrrr}2x-3y&=&6\\ 4x-6y&=&12\end{array} \qquad\ \ \ \text{(b)}\ \ \begin{array}{rrrrr}2x-3y&=&6\\ 4x-6y&=&10\end{array}\]

Solution

You should first have checked \(\begin{vmatrix}2 & -3\\ 4 & -6\end{vmatrix}\) since \[\begin{vmatrix}2 & -3\\ 4 & -6\end{vmatrix}=-12-(-12)=0.\]

Hence there is no unique solution in either case.

In system (a) the second equation is twice the first so there are infinitely many solutions. (Here we can give \(y\) any value we wish, \(t\) say; but then the \(x\) value is always \((6+3t)/2\). So for each value of \(t\) there are values for \(x\) and \(y\) which simultaneously satisfy both equations. There is an infinite number of possible solutions.)

In (b) the equations are inconsistent (since the first is \(2x-3y=6\) and the second is \(2x-3y=5\) which is not possible). Hence there are no solutions.
